This report was prepared by A. Sharma.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Government  of  Pakistan’s  sustained  commitment  to  structural  reforms  has 
contributed to economic growth during the fiscal year 2003 at a pace not seen in the last 6 
years. Agriculture, manufacturing, and services all recorded higher growth. This growth has set 
the stage for deepening the ongoing reforms to consolidate the gains and initiate second-
generation  reforms,  including  in  the  priority  sectors  of  agriculture  and  small  and  medium 
enterprises (SMEs)1 where access to affordable and adequate credit is still one of the main 
constraints.  To  supplement  the  ongoing  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  assistance  for 
agriculture, microfinance, rural finance, and SME sector reforms,2 the Country Strategy and 
Program  (2002-2006)  includes  an  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)3  grant  in  2003  for 
strengthening secured transactions4 to further enhance access to  credit for agriculture and 
SMEs. An ADB fact-finding mission visited Pakistan in February 2003. This TA report reflects 
the  understanding  reached  with  the  Government  on  objectives,  scope,  cost,  financing, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Credit to farmers and rural and urban SMEs, or debtors in general, flow from three major 
sources or creditors:5 savers, debtors themselves, and financial intermediaries such as banks. 
The savers can directly provide funds to debtors, such as by way of bonds, and indirectly 
through deposits in banks that lend to debtors. Debtors themselves provide credit to their buyers 
and receive credit from their suppliers. Credit at each level is secured by real and/or movable 
property through conventional forms of security interest that include pledges, floating charges, 
hypothecation, and mortgages; conditional sales with retentions or reversion of titles; and 
assignment of rights to accounts receivables that secure a loan. Movable collaterals, relevant 
for farmers and SMEs, include those (i) that can be easily identified, such as tractors; (ii) that 
cannot be specifically identified, such as grain in silos; and (iii) being transformed during 
processing  such  as  agriculture  produce.  The  list  extends  to  cover  current  assets  and 
receivables;  intangibles  such  as  trademarks,  patents,  credit  sales  contracts;  and  goods, 
including crops yet to be produced.  
 
3.  Fixed and movable property complement each other in the capital stock. For instance, 
equipment and inventories need to be located on real property to set up an SME. As economies 
modernize or aim to modernize, the significance of movable collateral grows. However, relative 
to the use of real property, the use of  movable property as collateral is not widespread in

4  A secured transaction, regardless of its form, is intended to create a security interest in movable and immovable 
property. A security interest is a right given to one party to secure payment or performance of an obligation. 
Collateral constitutes the asset over which security is granted.  
5  Banks, enterprises or producers, and nonbank creditors (traders, input suppliers, wholesalers, retailers) can be 
either creditors or debtors, or both.

2    
Pakistan.6 This is due to both generic issues in secured transactions and issues that are specific 
to movable property. Secured transactions in Pakistan, as in the region, are affected by the 
time, cost, and uncertainty in (i) establishing claim to the property to secure payment of credit, 
while allowing the debtor to retain possession of the collateral; (ii) prioritizing claims; (iii) 
publicizing the ranking of the priority; and (iv) taking possession of the collateral for sale to 
satisfy the claim. Gaps exist in coverage of movable properties and types of creditors and 
debtors as well as transactions. While registration lies at the heart of secured transactions, only 
a narrow range of security in movable property can be publicized by registration.  Although 
security may be created on movable assets owned and/or possessed by unincorporated entities 
including sole proprietorships, registration of such security is limited to companies only. This 
excludes most farmers and SMEs.  
 
4.  The underutilization of movables as collateral has economic impacts. If debtors are 
unable to use their movables as collateral while at the same time retaining the property for 
productive use in their business, such debtors in their role as producers and traders will provide 
little suppliers credit to their customers, thus limiting the potential scale of operations. Farmers 
and SMEs rarely have sufficient land or access to guarantors, which limits their access to credit 
and increases the cost of credit. Moreover, the amount of credit is determined more by the 
network of relationships, rather than by contract as a modern economy would demand. These 
factors restrict the growth of SMEs in Pakistan where the bulk of SMEs are engaged in trade 
and services (51% and 35%, respectively), and have most of their assets in inventories and 
receivables. As the economy evolves into the domain of digital economy, one of the country’s 
priorities (footnote 1), a secured transactions regime for movables becomes more important. 
The value of new economy enterprises is typically based on intangibles such as patents, 
copyrights,  brand  names,  and  software  codes.  Further,  accounts  receivables  comprise  a 
significant proportion of their assets. As most of these entrepreneurs start as SMEs, absence of 
an effective secured transactions regime for movables will affect new technology enterprises.  
 
5.  A large rural sector and widespread poverty magnifies the problems. While at the lower 
end of the rural finance market social pressure is used to secure microloans, the middle 
segment comprising small farmers and SMEs has little real property or imperfect title to small 
parcels of land that cannot provide access to adequate and affordable medium- to long-term 
credit. The Government response through credit quota and guarantee instead of augmenting 
the supply of credit raises the risk profile of rural credit and deters commercial banks  from 
expanding their rural credit portfolio. The inadequate institutional arrangement for issue of land 
passbooks also affects rural credit outreach. While the low repayment rate of rural credit, at 
60%, can be attributed to many reasons, lack of an effective mechanism for repossession of 
collateral encourages willful defaults. Due to these reasons, the rural credit market remains 
shallow and lacks variety and range in the services provided. Banks meet less than one-fifth of 
the potential rural credit demand.7 In addition, inadequate use of movables as collateral also 
impacts the microloan outreach, as microloan providers, including input traders and suppliers, 
are unable to use their loan portfolios as collateral for credit to refinance microloan operations.8  
 
6.  Despite the legal and institutional constraints, an effective secured transactions regime 
is well within the grasp of Pakistan.  The issues (paras. 3-5) can be addressed through a 
framework for secured transactions that (i) seeks and allows comprehensive registration of all

security interests irrespective of their legal form; (ii) permits individuals, partnerships, and other 
entities that are not companies to obtain effective access to credit based on security interests in 
movable  property  while  retaining  possession  of  the  property;  (iii)  contributes  to  improved 
transparency in determining the creditworthiness of debtors including information on the priority 
of other creditors to the collateral offered; and (iv) reduces transaction time and costs by 
fostering efficient creditor- and debtor-initiated settlement mechanisms instead of recourse to 
the overburdened judicial system.9 While the cost of such reforms is moderate, the benefits 
could translate into several percentage point gains in economic growth.10 
 
7.  Reducing  risk  through  an  effective  secured  transactions  regime  can  lead  to  lower 
lending  interest  rates  and  increase  the  supply  of  credit,  thus  supplementing  the  ongoing 
agriculture, microfinance, rural finance, and SME sector reforms (para. 1) being supported by 
ADB. While these reforms address demand and supply constraints for ensuring greater access 
of  farmers  and  SMEs  to  credit,  secured  transactions  reform  is  also  necessary  to  build 
confidence in the promissory nature of financial transactions and  facilitate diversification of 
credit risk and financial intermediation by encouraging nonbank creditors.11 Furthermore, an 
effective  secured  transactions  regime  facilitates  futures  trading  in  agricultural  commodities 
including the functioning of commodity exchanges,12 and will also enhance the potential benefits 
of  ADB-pipeline  projects  for  housing,  microfinance,  agribusiness,  and  public-private 
infrastructure. 
 
8.  The TA will help the Government develop an integrated reform framework for unleashing 
the economic potential of collateral as an instrument for securing financial transactions, while 
providing adequate debtor protection for the vulnerable groups.13 Secured transactions reform 
can make a key contribution to employment generation and poverty reduction. Experience 
shows that society gains from the reduced cost of supplying credit and from the gains in total 
output that arise from credit expansion made possible through the expanded pool of assets that 
can be used as collateral. 
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Outputs  
 
9.  The  TA  will  assist  the  Government  in  developing  a  secured  transactions  reform 
framework that can facilitate the creation, perfection, and enforcement of collateral interest by 
improving laws, regulations, and institutions. Secured transactions reform require patient and 
sensitive consensus building, as it needs to consider a variety of laws such as those relating to 
civil procedure, registration, contract, and companies. Sustained awareness and exposure are 
therefore required for developing a sequenced approach to secured transactions reform14 in the 
context  of  ongoing  economy-wide  structural  adjustment,  including  ADB-supported  sector 
reforms (paras. 1 and 7).

10.  The TA will support the development of a secured transactions legal reform framework 
and design of a modern registration system through comprehensive analysis and extensive 
consensus and awareness building efforts. The secured transactions legal reform framework 
and design of a modern registration system developed with TA assistance will be harmonized 
with good governance practices, efforts to support the private sector, and laws on social 
protection of debtors and consumer protection. In addition, the TA will assess the problems in 
providing land passbooks to small farmers and suggest means to mitigate such problems in the 
context of existing laws.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
 
11.  To accomplish its objectives, the TA will be implemented in 2 phases. 
  
12.  Draft Secured Transactions Reform Framework. In phase 1, a diagnostic study will (i) 
assess existing laws, regulations, and institutions relating to secured transactions and estimate 
the potential economic impact of the reforms, with particular reference to agriculture and SME 
sectors; and (ii) set out secured transactions reform options with suggested sequencing to be 
discussed  at  a  consensus-building  stakeholder  workshop.15 After incorporating stakeholder 
comments, a draft secured transactions reform framework with legal, economic, and institutional 
annotations will be prepared and discussed at another stakeholder workshop. The revised draft 
secured transactions reform framework will then be posted on the web sites of stakeholders for 
wider publicity.  
 
13.  Ministry of Finance (MOF), in consultation with ADB, will select secured transactions 
legal frameworks and accompanying registration systems in two countries for study-visits by 6 
persons each. Following the study-visits, a stakeholder workshop will be conducted to discuss 
the  secured  transactions  legal  and  regulatory  framework  needed  to  support  a  modern 
registration system in Pakistan. Thereafter, the draft secured transactions reform framework 
(para. 12) will be revised through consultant inputs to support a modern registration system 
taking account of (i) experience from countries that have undertaken such reforms, (ii) legal 
design input drawn from relevant ADB regional TA reports, and (iii) relevant Pakistan legal 
reports. The consultants will use these inputs for preparing a policy, legal, regulatory, and 
institutional  design  input  report.  A  stakeholder  workshop,  with  ADB  participation,  will  be 
conducted to review this report for the TA to continue to phase 2.  
 
14.  Secured  Transactions  Legal  Reform  Framework16  and  Design  of  a  Modern 
Registration System. Using the policy, legal, regulatory, and institutional design input report 
(para.  13),  the  consultants  will  prepare  in  phase  2  a  secured  transactions  legal  reform 
framework and the design of a modern registration system, with due regard to accessibility and 
affordability to farmers and SMEs. The equipment, software, staffing, and fee structure for the 
registration system will be assessed. In addition, the feasibility of a private sector and/or public-
private  partnership  model  for  the  registration  system  will  be  studied.  Two  stakeholder 
awareness-building workshops will be conducted covering both the secured transactions legal 
reform framework and the design of a modern registration system. At the end of the TA, MOF 
will identify at least two participants as nodal points and the TA reports will be posted on the 
web sites of all the participating agencies.  
 
                                                 
15 The Ministry of Finance in consultation with ADB will select the workshop participants.  
16 Based on the TA findings, this could include a secured transactions law or amendments to existing laws, or both.

C.  Cost and Financing  
 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent, consisting of $255,000 in 
foreign exchange and $370,000 equivalent in local currency. ADB will provide on a grant basis, 
under ADB’s TA funding program, the entire foreign exchange cost and $245,000 equivalent of 
the local currency cost. The Government will finance the remaining local currency cost of 
$125,000 equivalent in kind. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  MOF will be the executing agency for the TA. For TA implementation, MOF will form a 
TA steering committee comprising representatives from State Bank of Pakistan (SBP), the 
central bank; SME Bank; Zarai Taraqiati Bank Limited; Khushhali Bank; Ministry of Food, 
Agriculture, and Livestock; Ministry of Law, Justice, Human Rights, and Parliamentary Affairs; 
Ministry  of  Industries  and  Production;  and  SME  Development  Authority.  The  TA  steering 
committee, through its chairperson designate, will be responsible for overall implementation. 
SBP, the implementing agency, on behalf of MOF will implement and coordinate the studies, 
analysis, and outputs under the TA. SBP will provide office space, one counterpart staff, and 
support services at its head office.  
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 15 months beginning in February 2004 and completed 
by June 2005. Four tripartite review meetings involving the TA steering committee, the TA 
consultants, and ADB will be organized by SBP during the TA in conjunction with ADB missions 
to review implementation and resolve any outstanding issue. The meetings will be chaired by 
MOF. The TA will require 6 person-months of international and 35 person-months of domestic 
consulting inputs in secured transactions law and registration system, economic and financial 
analyses, nonbank and SME credit, and workshop facilitation. The terms of reference for 
consulting services are in Appendix 3. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for 
engaging domestic consultants. The quality- and cost-based selection method with simplified 
technical proposals will be used in selecting the consulting firm.  
 
18.  The TA consultants will prepare (i) an inception report including a detailed work program, 
to be submitted within 3 weeks of the start of the TA and to be discussed at the initial tripartite 
review meeting; (ii) quarterly progress reports on overall work progress during the period under 
review, the work program for the following quarter, and any outstanding issue; (iii) two interim 
reports, presenting draft outputs to be submitted within 6 months of the start of the TA for phase 
1 and within 12 months of the start of the TA for phase 2, and to be discussed at the interim 
tripartite review  meetings for phase 1 and phase 2; (iv) a draft final report compiling all TA 
activities and consultants’ recommendations, to be submitted at least 1 month before TA 
completion and to be discussed at the final tripartite review meeting; and (v) a final report at the 
completion of the TA. MOF and SBP will undertake a final evaluation of the TA jointly with ADB, 
based on the draft final report. The consultants will finalize the draft final report, based on the 
conclusions reached at the final tripartite review meeting.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Pakistan for Strengthening Secured Transactions, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

 TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES  
 
A.  Secured Transactions Expert-Legal (domestic, team leader [TL], 12 person-months; 
international, 3 person-months) 
 
1.  The  TL  will  have  a  postgraduate  qualification  in  law  and  in-depth  10  years 
postqualification exposure to secured transactions law as applied in Pakistan.1 The international 
expert will have 5 years of demonstrated experience in secured transactions law in developing 
and developed countries, of which at least one country should have a comprehensive legal and 
institutional framework for secured transactions.  
 
2.  The experts will 
 
(i)  review current laws including Islamic laws, regulations, and practices relating to 
secured transactions in Pakistan and identify major gaps; 
  
(ii)  consult  with  stakeholders  in  assessing  the  impediments  in  establishing  an 
effective secured transactions regime; 
 
(iii)  within the overall guidance of State Bank of Pakistan (SBP), the implementing 
agency, organize a consensus-building workshop and develop the workshop 
program and agenda; 
 
(iv)  organize  expert  resource  persons  who  will  participate  as  needed  in  the 
stakeholder workshop and also act as resource persons at the workshop;  
 
(v)  prepare a draft secured transactions reform framework with legal, economic, and 
institutional annotations tailored for Pakistan, taking into account (a) experience 
from other countries—including two developing countries—that have undertaken 
such  reforms  and  prepare  an  accessible  comparison  matrix  across  such 
countries; (b) relevant Asian Development Bank (ADB), Pakistan, and other 
reports  and  case  studies;  and  (c)  stakeholder  workshop  inputs;  specifically 
review the experiences of other countries, including two developing countries, for 
enhancing  governance  in  secured  financing  and  identify  lessons  and  best

secured transactions reform framework with laws on social protection of debtors,

(vi)  within the overall guidance of SBP organize a workshop to discuss the draft

C.  Nonbank Credit Expert-Rural (domestic, 3 person-months) 
 
7.  The expert will have in-depth understanding of the rural credit market, its participants, 
products, and services. The expert will be a graduate with 5-year work experience with rural 
finance institutions or nonbank creditors. Published work on the subject is desirable.  
 
8.  The expert, reporting to the TL, will  
 
(i)  identify and describe nonbank creditors including nongovernment organizations, 
input traders, wholesalers, retailers, enterprises, and farmers that provide credit 
for agriculture and small and medium enterprises (SMEs); draw credit chains 
across subsectors of the rural economy such as agriculture, enterprises, trading, 
transport, etc, to describe the linkages, e.g., creditors will themselves require 
credit for extending suppliers credit to the next participant in the credit chain; 
analyze collateral- and noncollateral-based products and services in the credit 
chains  including  the  terms  and  conditions  on  which  they  are  received  and 
extended; assess the role of collateral and its substitutes in the credit chains, the 
impediments in facilitating the use of collateral, and the consequences in terms of 
access as well as cost of credit; and  
 
(ii)  as determined by the TL, provide inputs from creditors’ and debtors’ perspectives 
for designing a  secured transactions legal reform framework and design of a 
modern registration system that ensures greater access of farmers and rural 
producers to secured credit through appropriate rural intermediaries; and assist 
the TL in submission of reports to MOF, SBP, and ADB.
